Read-Aloud Card: All Aboard the Bullet Train!
Introduce compound words and silent letters (wr, kn, gn).
Model how to blend compound words and words with silent letters (wr, kn, gn).
Explain that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Have students listen to the sounds on the Articulation Video. Then display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Explain that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Model identifying the two smaller words in the compound word
. Read each smaller word then blend them together to read the compound word. Model using the meanings of the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the compound word.
Model identifying the silent letter spelling in
Guide students to make compound words using the following smaller words:
Then have them identify the silent letter in each word.
(Add words with skills your students need to review.)
We like to make a snowman after a big snowstorm.
Do you play baseball or football?
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Read Aloud: All Aboard the Bullet Train!
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Have students whisper-read The Legend of the Talking Feather from Unit 18, Lesson 9 to build fluency.
Review Phonics/Syllable Cards and Word Cards
Use Phonics/Syllable Cards 5984 and High-Frequency Word Cards 161180 in the
Circulate, listen in, and provide corrective feedback.
Note high-frequency words and phonics skills for which students need additional support.
Include and highlight these words in activities throughout the upcoming lessons.
Display one Phonics/Syllable Card at a time.
Have students chorally say the sound(s).
When completed, mix the cards and repeat.
Then select a few cards and place them in a pocket chart or on the desk.
Call out the sound(s), and have students find the matching Phonics/Syllable Card with the spelling.
Repeat with the High-Frequency Word Cards.
Corrective Feedback: For high-frequency words students misread, say the word. Have students repeat, chorally spell, trace and spell, then repeat again.

. Have students add vowels, single consonants, blends, and digraphs to each pattern to see how many words they can make. Have them record their word lists.

Ask students to say each pictures name. Guide students to read the sentence on the back of the card. Offer support.
Then guide them to build the word with Letter Cards. They can self-correct using the word on the back of the card.
Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Next Stop, Grandparents!
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Personal Response
Have students write about the activity they think was most fun at Kates grandparents home.
Allow students to orally share with a partner what they want to write before writing.
Prompt them to look back at the story for support in writing.
Students can complete the writing during independent work time.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Ask students to share their ideas about what the words Next Stop might mean. Then confirm or correct their ideas by explaining that it is what a driver of a bus, or a conductor on a train might say.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
countryside, or the opposite of the city.
There are many trees and much wildlife in the
What would you see in a
place that you might not see in a city?
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names what the kids could ride where Kate lives. (skateboards)
What were the first two things Kate saw on her train ride? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How did Kates feelings about life in a rural area change by the end of the story?
Would you like to spend a summer in the city or the country? Why?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.

Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
What syllables do you hear in
? (chil-dren) Look at the beginning of the word. It contains the smaller word
. That helps us remember how to spell it because the words are connected: one child, many children.

The /n/ sound transfers to most languages. However, the graphemes (spelling patterns) kn and gn do not transfer.

Practice articulation with a few simple high-utility words and phrases, such as knee, knock, and I know ____. Model correct mouth position. Then have students copy the words to practice writing the letters and reading words with this silent letter spelling.
Write key sentences about writing tools that were used during different time periods on sentence strips.
Guide students to read each sentence.
Then ask students to arrange the sentences in order of the time the tool was used, and read each completed sentence.
Write each high-frequency word on a card or display the High-Frequency Word Card.
Say the word, and have students chorally read it.
Then have students build the word with Letter Cards.
When completed, have them write the word.
Prompt students to state and write a sentence using the word.

Have them draw a picture for each fact on their list.

Have students circle words with silent letters and compound words. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.

Contrast types of sentences. For example, contrast a sentence that asks a question with one that gives an order. For example, ask how sentence 1 is different than sentence 2. (Sentence 1 gives an order to wrap and ends with a period;  sentence 2 begins with the word
and ends with a question mark.) Repeat by contrasting sentences 4 and 7. Then contrast questions 2, 7, and 10 by focusing on the question word that each one starts with.
Bring blending words to life through the Living Words activity. Students build the words as they stand in front of the class holding large letter cards.

Remind students that a compound word is a word made up of two smaller words. Then read the word
. Point out that sometimes the two smaller words can help readers figure out the meaning of the compound word:
A bookstore is a store that sells books.
. Circle the two smaller words in each compound word. Read each smaller word and then the whole compound word. Have students repeat. Guide students to figure out the meaning of each compound word.

. Guide students to identify the smaller words and then read and define each compound word.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.
Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Riddles to Ride.
Dictate the following sentences for students to write, one at a time:
Who wrote the letter in your mailbox? The sound you hear is someone knocking at the door.
Read the title. Explain that this text contains four riddles about different ways to travel. Ask students to tell what they know about riddles. Encourage volunteers to share any riddles they know.

For the first reading, you read the riddle. Have students guess the answer and then tell which clues helped them solve the riddle. Confirm the answers. For other readings, have one partner read a riddle and the other tell the answer, then switch roles and repeat.
Prompt students to circle all the compound words and words with silent letters. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

and have students repeat. Circle the two smaller words  (tooth, brush) and remind students that the two smaller words may help them figure out the meaning of the compound word. For example:

Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Bikes Then and Now.
Have students write the word Bicycles at the top of the page and draw lines to connect three boxes to the word.
Ask students to write an important fact they learned about bicycles from each date listed.

Then ask them to use these facts to write a summary of the selection. Have students share their summaries with a partner and identify facts that are included in both summaries and facts that are unique to each partners summary.

Identify open syllables: End in a vowel and have a long vowel sound. When one consonant appears between two vowels, divide the word before and after the consonant, and blend together the parts to see which part forms a word you have heard:
